The Principle of Self-Management The Rangatiratanga Principle The iwi have the right to organise as iwi, and, under the law, to control their resources as their own. Ibid. 11 The New Zealand Maori Council has explained the concept of Rangatiratanga as meaning more than `possession': `it means the wise administration of all the assets possessed by a group for that group's benefit: in a word, trusteeship' (Te Wahanga Tuatahi, 1983, p 5) In the Crown's view, the First and Second Articles of the Treaty are both strong statements which necessarily qualify one another. Kawanatanga is subject to a promise to protect Rangatiratanga. Rangatiratanga is subject to an acknowledgment of Kawanatanga. The working out in practice of the balance between the two Articles must depend upon a case by case consideration. ... It is the right of all citizens, Maori, Pakeha, and other New Zealanders, that there be effective Government or Kawanatanga in such matters.
More insidiously, the actual terms of the treaty such as "rangatiratanga" and "full and exclusive possession" are being redefined to proscribe Maori rights.
The first, on behalf of the Whakatohea iwi, is seeking rangatiratanga and kaitiakitanga - authority and guardianship - over a 50km stretch of Bay of Plenty coastline east of Whakatane.

Author: KIRK
Quote: It is invariably erect and never climbing, although bushmen and settlers frequently state that it climbs the loftiest trees, and sooner or later squeezes them to death in its iron clasp. In proof of this they assert that, when felling huge ratas, they often find a dead tree in the centre of the rata: this is a common occurrence, but it by no means follows that this species is a climber. The error is simply due to imperfect observation, which has led careless observers to confuse [M. scandens the Aka], which is a true climber with M. robusta.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Rata, n. Maori name for two New Zealand erect or sub-scandent flowering trees, often embracing trunks of forest trees and strangling them: the Northern Rata, Metrosideros robusta , A. Cunn., and the Southern Rata, M. lucida , Menz., both of the N.O. Myrtacea . The tree called by the Maoris Aka, which is another species of Metrosideros (M. florida) , is also often confused with the Rata by bushmen and settlers. In Maori, the adj. rata means red-hot, and there may be a reference to the scarlet appearance of the flower in full bloom. The timber of the Rata is often known as Ironwood , or Ironbark . The trees rise to sixty feet in height; they generally begin by trailing downwards from the seed deposited on the bark of some other tree near its top. When the trailing branches reach the ground they take root there and sprout erect. For full account of the habit of the trees, see quotation 1867 (Hochstetter), 1879 (Moseley), and 1889 (Kirk).

ra[a]ta[a], a tree (Metrosideros spp.), crimson flower that covers the trees with sheets of colour: it may start in a fork of any tree, and sends down rootlets that grow in size till they surround the [146] tree and strangle it, when the rata stands on its own. rata : tree with scarlet flowers.

I recall his [the botanist-Inspector's] chuckle when we showed him ... the huge white caterpillar known throughout bushland [in North Auckland] as the `rata grub', so-called because it was always found at the foot of a rata and was supposed to be the origin [101] of the tree itself. It is a curious creature - a great caterpillar with a strange tree-like fungoid growth, growing sometimes to a height of several inches, from its body. I think everybody believed in the legend of the rata-tree caterpillar; ...
We then talked about the rata grub. The gentleman told us it was only a tale about it growing into a rata tree, and the tale had arisen from seeing a seed of the tree sprouting in the grub.

Rations.-. Pronounced to rhyme with `nations', not with `passions' as in the army. The r. system went out of general use in Canterbury in the 'seventies. The old scale was 16lb meat, 10lb flour, 2lb sugar, l/4 lb tea a man a week; or sometimes 12lb meat, 12lb flour, 2lb sugar, and 1/4 lb tea. (C.)

The flower, stem, and leaves, enclosed in the above letter when I received it, were those of the sporobolus elongatus, in some districts called "ratstail grass," in others "Chilian grass," and probably a dozen or two local names, for all I know to the contrary. It is a native of the province of Auckland, and of late years has been spreading rapidly, in consequence of the extension of agriculture.

At noon we stopped at a small settlement called Kiatoka, where we made a meal of some tuies toasted in the leaf of a tree called herarekau, these leaves will not burn, and they are wrapped round the bird so that none of the fat can escape, the bird cooked in this manner is really very delicious.

We had some eels for breakfast, cooked in a way which was new to most of us, called kohe or kope, and which is done in the following manner:- fern stalks are run down the whole length of the fish (which is not skinned or in any way prepared for cooking) from the mouth to the tail - then two eels thus skewered are wrapped in leaves of the raurekau tree, and tied together with flax, when they are roasted before the fire with one end resting on the ground and the other leaning against a stick supported in a horizontal position in front of the fire for the purpose.

Author: WALL
Quote: Sowthistle . Here I note a case of what is called `folk etymology'. I hear this native plant (and introduced weed) as `sour thistle'. The speaker mistrakenly supposes the plant to be named from its taste. It is actually edible and much used by the Maoris as rauriki, corruptly `radicky'.
rauriki n -s [Maori, fr. rau leaf + riki small] NewZeal
... the sow thistle, better known as `rauriki' in the Wellington district, which, marketed [in East Coast and Rotorua districts] as `puha' finds a ready sale.

If he were sure he could recognise it, writes Mr T. P. Moloney, he would gather rauriki and get his wife to cook it, for he enjoyed it years ago in Maori cooking, in the King Country, where it was called by the pakeha `Maori cabbage.' Rauriki is the common succulent thistle, growing 2ft to 3ft high, that the children gathering it for pet rabbits and guinea pigs, call milk thistle, because of the abundant flow of milky white sap from it. Actually there are two species' Sonchus oleraceus, whose lobed leaves are only mildly prickly and flat, or at the most very slightly waved at the edges, and S. asper, very similar except that the leaves are much more prickly, and are waved or crimped around the edges. The flowers are yellow, rather like those of a dandelion, about three-quarters of an inch in diameter. Chewing Gum According to some people, rauriki is the Maori name of the former and puwha of the latter, but I do not know that the Maoris went in for such nice distinctions. Different tribes had different names for the same thing. Puwha, as well as being one of the names for the sow thistle, seems to have been also used sometimes as a general term for any cooked greens, of which sow thistle was the favourite.

At Oxford, Makereti (Maggie Papakura) wrote: `I myself gather the sow thistle here and cook it to eat, as it reminds me of our own puwha, of which I am very fond. Puwha was used only as a vegetable ... The succulent stems contained a bitter milky juice which came to the surface when the flower tops were plucked off. This was left, on a sunny day, for a few hours, then gathered between the thumb and first finger, adding the thick creamy mass of several plants together. This was used as a sort of chewing gum, called pia or ngau, which tasted very bitter at first. But after a little chewing, the bitterness disappeared, and this gum was much enjoyed, especially by the women, who vied with each other in seeing who could make her pia crack the loudest.'
rauriki [=] sow thistle [s]

The locomotive steamed to its new home with another older loco, but when the two reached the foot of the legendary Raurimu Spiral, the boiler of the older locomotive failed.
The Raurimu Spiral was one of the most wonderful engineering feats in the world.
It has been said that the Raurimu Spiral would never have been constructed if aeroplanes had existed when the reconnaissance surveys were made.
Had they not heard that we have the unique Raurimu Spiral, the amazing span of the Mohaka viaduct and the death-defying precipice of Staircase Gully?

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: BLIND TORPEDO RAY OR NUMBFISH Typhlonarke aysoni (Hamilton) [ibid. 92]. This uncommon fish has several names, all of which relate to its manner of producing electric shocks, some of which are Numb-fish, Crampfish and Electric Skate. These vernacular names are given by fishermen on account of the fish benumbing or paralysing the person who unwittingly grasps one with his hands. The last name is from the somewhat similar shape to that of a skate or ray, ray being another common term for skates and also the scientific family name.

Our chances are certainly better than they would have been during the depths of the recolonial era. Ibid. C5 These problems are less likely to be resolved if we fail to recognise their recolonial roots.
The recolonial era hid or denied difference, emphasised harmony, and played up Britishness. Belich's book traces a Great Tightening that shaped much of New Zealand life during recolonialism.

Belich divides the period covered by the volume, the 1880s to the present, into three broad phases: the progressive colonisation which was the dominant feature of Making Peoples; the rise of recolonisation, which tightened the relations between Britain and colonies up to the 1960s and made them co-owners of imperial culture and heritage; and finally decolonisation, the period since the 1960s in which New Zealand has achieved economic diversification, greater independence in foreign policy and a great socio-demographic "coming-out" of difference.
But one pattern looms high above the rest, recolonisation, whose rise, reign and fall is the master variable of modern New Zealand history.

By recolonisation he means the powerful tightening of economic, social and cultural ties to Britain that began in the 1880s and lasted till the 1970s. It turned New Zealand into "a town-supply district of London" while "London became the cultural capital of New Zealand."

In fact, New Zealand remained a colony, albiet a privileged one, from the 1880s till the 1960s. Belich dubs this era, which followed four decades of colonisation, as New Zealand's "recolonised" period. It was a time of tightened economic and cultural links to Britain and a role for this country as Britains "town supply district".

We sometimes are surprised at the sudden appearance of a great Red Admiral butterfly in our rooms in midwinter.

The red admiral, as I have called this butterfly, though it is not the same as the insect of that name so well known to English lepidopterists, is said to live in the larval stage only on the nettle. In the face of the abundance of the mature insects and the scarcity of nettles, this is a statement requiring verification ...
I have even seen specimens of the large "Red Admiral" butterfly caught in the flowers.

Near the Nairn we found a clump of the Chatham Island nettle, a fine plant with very large leaves, interesting to the entomologist as it is simply alive with the larvae of Pyrameis gonerilla - our Red Admiral butterfly.

Tawhai Tawhairaunui, Black-birch of Auckland and Otago (from colour of bark), Red-birch of Wellington and Nelson (from colour of timber). --This is a noble tree 60-90 feet high the trunk 5-8 feet in diameter. The timber is excessively tough and hard to cut. It is highly valued in Nelson and Wellington.

[Notho]fagus fusca, Hook. f. ... Tooth-leaved Beech. Black Birch of Auckland and in part of Otago and Southland. Black or Bull Birch of Lake Wakatipu. Red Birch of Wellington, Nelson, and in part of Otago and Southland. It is not so easy to see why any difficulty should have occured in the identification of this fine timber-tree apart from the misleading tendency of the common names generally applied. The thin yet firm texture of the leaf, the prominent veins, the sharply-toothed margins, are characters that can only be confused with those afforded by a careless observer. Yet merely owing to the use of common names based upon colour, and applied or rather misapplied to the leaves, bark, or wood at the fancy of the bushman, no species has been more misunderstood.

Author: HICKEY

I had no authority whatever for issuing the circular, and in looking back on that time now, can only account for my impetuous action through my anger at the contempt displayed towards organised Labour by the City Council and the press. The leaflet (which happened to be printed on red paper, this giving the idea to the `Evening Post' [in early 1912] that was responsible for the coining of the term `Red Federation,' which was afterwards abbreviated to `Red Fed.') caused a wave of militancy to sweep through the tramway service, and a meeting was called for the p.m. shift the following day.

Author: PARROTT
Quote: THE RED PERCH Caesioperca lepidoptera(Bloch & Schneider)... Maori name: OIA. Ibid. 73 The Red Perch, as is the case with many of our common fishes, has received many popular names. It is known in Australia as the `Bastard Long-fin', a name probably associated with its long dorsal fin. It is also known as the `Red Snapper', `St. Peter's Fish' or `Butterfly Perch'. It probably received the name of `St. Peter's Fish' on account of the two black marks, one on each side of the body, which suggest the thumb/and finger marks of St. Peter, as I have previously explained in the case of the John Dory.

Author: McDONALD
Quote: Q. Are there many harbours there [on the west side of New Zealand]? A. Several ... All covered with wood Q. Of what sort? A. Of white and red pine and a wood called `black oak'. Q. Is it of the species called `kaikatua'? A. It is. Q. Did you see any of the species called `cowrie'? A. I did not. Ibid. 1/560 Q. Whereabouts do the red and white pine trees grow? A. The white pine grows in wet swampy places. The red pine grows on the sides of hills. Q. Is the red pine like the cowrie? A. It is the same grain, but not the same color.

The chief indigenous trees of commercial value are: Kauri (Agathis Australis), Kahikatea or white pine (Podocarpus dacrydioides), rimu or red pine (Dacrydium cupresssinum ), totara (Podocarpus totara and Podocarpus Hallii), Miro (Podocarpus ferrugineus), Kaikawaka or mountain cedar (Libocedrus Bidwilli), yellow pine or silver pine (Dacrydium Colensoi and D. intermedium), red and hard beech (Nothofagus fasca and Nothofagus truncata), silver beech (Nothofagus Menziesii), black beech (Nothofagus Solandri), black maire (Olea Cunninghamii), northern and southern rata (Metrosideros robusta and Metrosideros lucida).

Red stickered: This block of Basin Reserve shops owned by the New Zealand Transport Agency is one of the first buildings in the city to be red stickered by Wellington City Council under its new policy to force owners to strengthen or demolish earthquake-prone buildings.

The red sticker is not a demolition order. It means the building is either so damaged there is a risk of collapse or nearby unstable buildings pose a safety threat. Civil Defence figures show that as of Thursday, 42 buildings have been demolished, with 94 partially "deconstructed".
The large four-storey brick mill in Wise St, Addington, was built at the turn of the 20th century but yesterday its fate was decided with a red sticker.

To their immense credit, our trio of hard-hats were wonderfully kind and quick to check on our emotional state. The inevitable did happen. The red sticker was produced. The old brick lady was wrapped in red tape, the warning notice was stuck on the garage door and the neighbour's garden cordoned off. Our house was deemed unsafe to inhabit. .. The red sticker was a moment of clarity. The house was unsafe while the aftershocks were occurring; walk away.
Experts in related fields were doing preliminary assessments to ease the workload although they could not recommend a red sticker.

A meeting with other owners of red-stickered homes on April 20 put them in touch with geotechnical consultant David Bell. Bell was the only official able to give a ruling, and proved to be a "lifesaver".
However, two remain red-stickered because of separate, structural issues.

Resident magistrates, especially in frontier districts, were agents of government as well as having judicial functions. The reti consists of a canoe-shaped board about a foot long with a spinning bait attached with about four feet of strong line. The board is thrown into the current on its edge and is held against the current and allowed to drift out into the breakers, generally on about 100 yards of line. The moment a fish is struck the whole affair is brought in.

Alison Nevill, of Dunedin, asks about the fascinating phrase "the whole rick-ma-tick". She says her Scottish grandmother employed a maid in the 40s who used it constantly, meaning something like "that's all there is to it". The maid came from Stirling, and the family always thought it was one of her home-town expressions, so when Alison got to New Zealand, she was surprised to hear it being used in the same context of finality. "The whole rick-ma-tick" has a long and honourable history as a Scottish version of "the whole kit and caboodle", an expression from the United States east coast that is widely understood here as an ornate alternative to "the whole lot".

When the nine provinces were abolished in 1876 the colony was divided for local government purposes into counties, regard being had to boundaries of existing road districts, and the counties were subdivided into ridings, each riding being empowered to elect a certain number of members of the Council of the county. The ridings comprise one or more of the above three districts. They have no governing body - they are simply the electoral divisions of the county, and their maximum number is nine.

Quote: Way (w&amacr.), n. [Add.] Right of way. [Add.] (b) (Pl., RIGHT OF WAYS.) A narrow street; a lane. [Australia] This use of the legal term in a concrete sense originated in Melbourne. These passages ran from one broad street to another and were intended to afford a right of way between the lots. Hence the term came to be applied to the passages themselves.

The idea is to ringbark the trees and bore through the trunk with an augur a couple of holes which are filled with a composition and plugged. The composition soaks into the wood, rots it, and causes it to become inflammable. In about eight or ten months a match is applied, and the tree falls, the stump and roots which have become soaked with the mixture, being burned right out.
The dead tree by the gas works has been cut down, and the gentleman who ring-barked it for impeding his zig-zag progress can now absorb his whisky with a comparatively easy mind.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Ring, v. (1) To cut the bark of a tree round the trunk so as to kill it. The word is common in the same sense in English forestry and horticulture, and only seems Australasian from its more frequent use, owing to the widespead practice of clearing the primeval forests and generally destroying trees. `Ringed' is the correct past participle, but `rung' is now commonly used. [1846] ... (2) to make cattle move in a circle. [1874] ... (3) To move round in a circle [1884] ... (4) To make the top score at a shearing-shed.' See Ringer.

ring v.t. to kill a tree by cutting the bark round the trunk; to make cattle move in a circle;-v.i. to move in a circle, as cattle or birds; to win in a sheep-shearing contest. -ring'er n. the man who shears most sheep in a day. - ring'-bark v.t. to ring a tree.-ring'-neck n. a newly arrived immigrant, esp. from England; a jackaroo

Author: ACLAND
Quote: Merino sheep on the flat, especially when coming to a gate, are apt to circle. The centre of the mob may stand still, or move slowly forward; but the outside sheep gallop round and round them. This is called ringing. It is annoying to see the sheep racing past the gate instead of going through it, but the habit may be turned to the shepherd's advantage. By starting the sheep on one side ringing the reverse way, two streams of sheep can be made to meet at the gate, and carry one another through.

Ringing Sheep: Fault in a dog where it goes in a complete circle around the sheep and comes back to the handler. It fails to stop after its out-run, halfway around the sheep, and directly opposite the handler.

Quote: The new genus, Ringanui, is a significant step in resolving this confusion. Ringanui differs from Paraleptamphopus on several characters and is most easily recognised by diverse gnathopods, the first of which is enlarged relative to gnathopod 2. The two species are described and illustrated in detail. They differ in size and gnathopod characteristics, but other differences are small. Ringanui koonuiroa is the smaller species and is most easily recognised by the single, very long robust seta defining the palm of gnathopod 1. The second species, R. toonuiiti, is the larger, but its palmar defining spine is relatively short.

At the native meeting up the river the diversity of religions caused some discussion. There are four religions altogether, Protestant (Church of England), Catholic, Salvation Army, and Te Kooti's religion (Ringatu). The latter is a bugbear to some of the natives, particularly the Catholics, but the meeting decided on freetrade in this matter, the main argument being that as Englishmen had hundreds of religions there was no reason why the Maoris should not have at least four. .. The term Ringatu is, we understand, derived from the fact that in place of saying "Amen," as usual in other services, they say "Glory."

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote: It is important to distinguish these `Action-Terms' of marbles from the innumerable merely descriptive marble terms which have no effect on the course of the action - terms such as Ringer, In, Smug, Dead Stick, Skun, Skinned, Sported off, Scat, Cannons, Dubs, Kills, Funs, Keeps, Pink.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote: Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs. Ibid. 176 [Waitara, Taranaki, 1899: reference, game of Little Ring] Many heated arguments arose as to who said `everythings' or `nothings' first. If a player's `taw' touched a marble and lay alongside it, the others would shout `knuckle down' just before his turn. ... `Knuckle down' meant that the player had to hold his taw close to the marble attacked and fire it in that very inconvenient position. ... When a boy lost all his marbles at play he was `scat' [?related to skint ?HWO] . ... A `ringer' was a taw which, when fired at the commencement of the game, lodged in the track of the ring itself; that, and knocking a marble out when he `fired' were the perfect shots. ... To fire a shot while holding the hand nearer to the ring than where the taw had lain, was to `funk', an unforgiveable crime.

The `riffleboard' was detachable and formed a `false bottom'. `Riffle' was probably a Californian term; `ripple' seems to have been more usual on the goldfields of Australasia.

There is a slight fall between each roller, on which are placed copper ripple plates, so that whatever gold is liberated by the crushing of the first roller has a chance to get amalgamated on the first copper ripples, and so with the second chamber, where the material passes through a rough grating before entering the third or last chamber, where it is retained until fine enough to go through a 240 punched grating, after which it is passed over the final copper ripples.
... the water and debris then ran down a sluice channel into boxes fitted with coconut matting and `ripple plates'; these caught and retained the gold which was collected at the regular `wash-up.'

It consisted of flour and water, with sugar [53] to sweeten, boiled and served up as a kind of porridge. In the early whaling days it was often served up to a whole village community from a canoe set up like a trough from which the villagers scooped their requirements in large bowls or paua shells. Author: McARA
Quote: Rise: A timbered excavation constructed by working upwards, using upper holes. Rising was done on the three-compartment system, that is with a ladderway on one end and a return airway on the other, with a `box' in the centre. This box was kept filled with ore and used to stand on while drilling the roof, the level of the ore being maintained by, drawing off the surplus ore through a chute at the bottom of the box. Rises were about 9 ft by 4 ft in section and might reach from one level to the next (about 150 ft), or to a sublevel, or from a stope to the level above.

This heavy stream, which breaks so suddenly on a stranger from its very rough surroundings, got its name (according to early-day tradition) from the fact that Meg, one of the two girls on their way to a dancing saloon at Arrow, created such a fuss at crossing this turbulent water that vibrations of her voice loosened rocks on the mountain side to add still further to the roaring of stream and of Meg herself. There are different versions concerning the naming of this stream, and maybe some of this one is my own. ... A few miles further on the next stream to be crossed is the Gentle Annie, called after Meg's pal, who no doubt was a much quieter type of tourist than Meg herself.

For a long time it has been known to the Maori and to Europeans that our New Zealand Whitebait is the young of a native freshwater fish commonly known as Minnow, or Inanga or Hiwi to the Maori, and erroneously called a Trout. ... The early settlers called it Maori Trout, Native Trout, Rock Trout and Minnow. But it is not a Trout. Nor is it a Minnow, through it resembles the English freshwater Minnow. While the name Trout is not correct, it is and will always be known as such by farmers and naturalists. In the Bay of Plenty, Whitebait is known to the Maori as Porohoe.

Quote: An article in the Building World, 1889, had this to say: `Logging the Kauri in New Zealand is a rather exciting occupation - that is by the `rolling road' method of extraction ...'

Flotation is the method most commonly used in the kauri districts ... After the trunks are cut into lengths a `rolling-road' is formed to the nearest creek. All the scrub is closely cut down for a width of from twenty-five to thirty feet ... to obtain an approximately even surface, inclined towards the creek. The logs are forced along this road by timber-jacks, which the bushmen use with remarkable skill, and are impelled with a rapidity which is simply astonishing to persons unused to the process. If the creek contains plenty of water the logs float to the nearest booms without further trouble ...

Author: REED
Quote: Hochstetter in 1889 and Kirk in 1874 [Report to Parliament], refer to rolling roads. Kirk describes them as `broad tracks, thirty to forty feet wide, in which every advantage is taken of the natural incline of the surface, and from which all trees have to be removed, the stumps cut level with the surface, inequalities roughly levelled, and large holes filled up. The logs are forced along these roads by `timberjacks' until they reach the water. In this way the logs are moved with great ease. ...[D.H.McMillan] Rolling roads were formed by laying three rickers or other small trees lengthwise to the line of road, and logs were placed crosswise on this road. There might be thirty or forty or more in a fleet. Three men with timber lacks usually operated this job.

... what was called the rolling road ... was anything up the 30 feet wide, with all the stumps cut down to ground level ... The heavy swirl and pressure of water was unable to twist the gold contents out of the pot hole, and so a store of gold collected in the bottom and might contain nuggets as well as dust.

Run.- The pioneers of sheep farming in New Zealand and Australia came from various classes; but there were few among them who had been sheep farmers before and fewer still who were scientists. If they had been sheep farmers they would probably have used the English or Scotch sheep farming words (as they did to some extent) and fitted them to the new conditions. If they had been scientists they would have invented exact names for everything new, and translated them into Latin. What they did do was to take the handiest word they could think of and give it a new meaning, As time went on the word they had chosen changed or extended its meaning. The best example of all this is the word run.
Notes: >Acland's senses 1 and 5 seem to be the central ones, with the others being specialisations of, or obvious inferences from those. -->cf also Morris

Quote: [Cont] (1) The country held under a particular lease or pastoral license. [sic] (PAUL, p. 92) (2) Group of rs. held by one owner, or in one station. The whole area is spoken of as a r. (C.RH., p. 90) (3) Leasehold as opposed to freehold. (Sheep returns, 1878) (4) Open as opposed to fenced country. `Out on the r.'; i.e., not in any of the paddocks. ([1874 Lady Barker Station Life], p. 62) (5) Adjective. R. sheep, r. cattle, as opposed to paddock sheep or milking cows and hand-reared calves. (C.) (6) As equivalent to station: e.g. `He has sold his r.'; `One of the best rs. in Canterbury.' In this sense r. did not always include the sheep, as the word s[tation]. does. This usage is now uncommon and r. in these contexts would probably mean small grazing r. ([1874 Kennaway Crusts], p. 86;Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement],p. 152) (7) A block of country, a division of a r. E.g. ewe r. upper r. This sense was always rare, but is still in use on some ss. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) (8) To keep or carry. `He runs merinos'; `the station runs 10,000 sheep' ([1898 Morris Austral-English]; C)

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Run, n. (1) Tract of land over which sheep or cattle may graze. It is curious that what in England is called a sheep-walk, in Australia is a sheep-run. In the Western United States it is a sheep -ranch. Originally the squatter, or sheep-farmer, did not own the land. It was unfenced, and he simply had the right of grazing or `running' his sheep or cattle on it. Subsequently, in many cases, he purchased the freehold, and the word is now applied to a large station- property, fenced or unfenced. (See quotation, 1883.) [1826]

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote: First a run is a parcel of land as leased. A sheepfarmer might own several adjacent runs of land, in this sense, and the whole `station' so formed might also be termed a run. In the third sense a run was leasehold as opposed to freehold land; in a fourth sense, open land as opposed to fenced land. It might be used as an adjective, e.g. run cattle. It might be the equivalent of station but without including the sheep, i.e. `He sold his run' need not imply that he sold his sheep, but `He sold his station' would.

run: [1] This word has several uses but the most common refers to a stretch of work. The official shearing time of two hours is called a `run'. The day is divided into four of these. 7.30am-9.30am, smoke-o; 10.00am-12 noon, dinner; 1.00pm-3.00pm smoke-o; 3.30pm-5.30pm, tea. [2] Also another name for a sheep station. [3] Also the contract circuit. A shearing contractor will arrange a `run' of sheds for his gang each season.

Author: SALMOND
Quote: Another kind of weatherboard which became popular in the 1880's was the "rusticated" board, where the top edge was planed down to fit behind a rebate in the edge of the next board. The completed wall showed pronounced grooves which resembled channel-jointed stonework, and in more elaborate houses timber quoins at corners assisted the illusion. The introduction of the rusticated board has been attributed to the Wellington architect Julius Toxward in the 1860s.
rusticated or rusticating n. (in New Zealand) a wide type of weatherboarding used in older houses.

Labour leader Helen Clark is questioning the appointment of one of the "high priests of Rogernomics and Ruthanasia" as the new head of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.
The leader, deputy and a handful of others are queasy about the Ruthanasia era. Who isn't?
They speak of a time before Rogernomics and Ruthanasia, when issues were clear-cut, and people still cared enough to put their bodies on the line for something bigger than themselves.

In 2002, Colin James argued that Helen Clark's government was operating during a period of consolidation, smoothing out some of the most glaring social inequalities created by the 1984-92 policy revolution, while consolidating the key economic changes of Rogernomics and Ruthanasia.

And for most of us, those sensual childhood delights intensify and deepen with age. "Let's go into the garden" becomes a universal cry from the heart that can be heard more often as the economic climate worsens and Ruthanasia (Mary Varnham's delightful term) rampages in the wake of Rogernomics unrelieved by shafts of light or the chiaroscuro effects to be found in the personal Eden of the garden.
What transformed the two major parties into the activist-based organisations they are today? Rogernomics and Ruthanasia.

Notes: By the time Rogernomics and Ruthanasia had run their course, New Zealanders had lost control of their finance sector, most of their news media, and much else besides.

Quote: If you doubt this, consider the electorate's rejection of Rogernomics in 1990, and Ruthanasia in 1993.
